Question: Idiom for getting unique pairs of collection elements in Java: :Is there a standard idiom for getting a set of each unique pair of elements in a given Collection?  For our purposes, the set of (a,b) is equivalent to (b,a), and thus only one should appear in the resulting set.I can see how one might construct such a set using a Pair class that implements hashCode and equals() based on the paired elements, but I'm wondering if there isn't already a more standard way to generate such a set.
Please using this api: Iterator.next.
Answer:
response:
Please answer my code questions using the given API following this format: <<<api>>>: $API
<<<code>>>: $CODE
<<<explanation>>>: $EXPLANATION.
Question: Idiom for getting unique pairs of collection elements in Java: :Is there a standard idiom for getting a set of each unique pair of elements in a given Collection?  For our purposes, the set of (a,b) is equivalent to (b,a), and thus only one should appear in the resulting set.I can see how one might construct such a set using a Pair class that implements hashCode and equals() based on the paired elements, but I'm wondering if there isn't already a more standard way to generate such a set.
Please using this api: Iterator.next.
Answer: <<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: 
```java
Set<Pair<T>> uniquePairs = new HashSet<>();
Iterator<T> iterator = collection.iterator();
while (iterator.hasNext()) {
    T a = iterator.next();
    if (iterator.hasNext()) {
        T b = iterator.next();
        uniquePairs.add(new Pair<>(a, b));
    }
}
```
<<<explanation>>>: This code creates a new HashSet to store the unique pairs. It then gets an iterator from the collection. In a loop, it checks if there is another element in the collection. If there is, it gets the next two elements and adds them to the set as a Pair. The Pair class must implement hashCode and equals() to ensure that duplicate pairs are not added.

```java
public class Pair<T> {
    private final T a;
    private final T b;

    public Pair(T a, T b) {
        this.a = a;
        this.b = b;
    }

    @Override
    public boolean equals(Object o) {
        if (this == o) return true;
        if (o == null || getClass() != o.getClass()) return false;
        Pair<?> pair = (Pair<?>) o;
        return (a.equals(pair.a) && b.equals(pair.b)) || (a.equals(pair.b) && b.equals(pair.a));
    }

    @Override
    public int hashCode() {
        return Objects.hash(a, b) + Objects.hash(b, a);
    }
}
```
This code will generate a set of unique pairs from a collection. The Pair class is used to ensure that each pair is unique, regardless of the order of the elements.

Note: This code assumes that the collection has at least two elements. If the collection may have less than two elements, you should add a check for this before entering the loop.
